VE doesn't support Linux x86_64 for SWT development yet.  See bug 87851.

I get a very similar traceback when I try exactly the same thing, and I'm not
running on AMD64. (Well, actually I am, but I'm running in a 32-bit chroot
environment, and this would be the first thing that's actually cared about the
difference ...)

Anyway, using:

eclipse.buildId=Gentoo Linux eclipse-sdk-3.1_rc1
java.version=1.5.0_03
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US

This is because the SWT container does not support the 64bit library path

The exception in this defect has been fixed a while ago, but the fact is that we
need to do not:

  Add 64bit SWT jars on an SWT project
  use the 64bit version of the screen scrape on GTK

Use this defect to fix this.

Jeff being in possession of a 64 bit machine attached a 64 bit .so file in the
defect 87851. We need to add that to the folder path of the VE plugin.

I added the 64 bit .so file to
org.eclipse.ve.swt\os\linux\x86_64\libswt-gtk-print.so provided in bug 87851.

Looking at the 64bit image structure, the current SWTContainer should support
them with no change.

The only thinng left, is for the screenScrape library if/then.
Jeff, when Sri releases the code to CVS, will you be able to sniff it.

Yup, I had it working pretty much out of the box once I had the library
recompiled.  However, as stated in bug 87851 the references to the Widget.handle
in ImageCapture.java have to be switched over to longs for it to compile against
the 64 bit version of swt, and to match the jni headers of the native library.

Unfortuantely I no longer have a 64 bit version of linux running on my AMD 64
box (long story).  

Jamie, could you test it out?

Peter, can you drive a nightly build and make it available.  Jamie, if you can
pick up that build, and verify on your machine, it will be great if you can
leave a comment here.

Just released a 64 bit ImageCapturer
(org.eclipse.ve.internal.swt.targetvm.unix.bits64.ImageCapture) which should
handle the regular x86 64bit (x86_64) and the Itanium based 64bit (ia64)
platforms. Also added in a new .so library file for ia64 (copy of x86_64's .so
file).

Jeff, since you have a 64bit AMD (with 32bit OS installed) I was wondering if
you could boot your system with any 64bit linux Live CDs and test this out once
Peter makes a build? I was able to find out Ubuntu live CD which boots to a
64bit linux system (http://us.releases.ubuntu.com/releases/5.04/).

Jamie, yours seems to be an AMD system too - could you please try it out once a
build is made.

Would be nice to find someone with an Itanium 64 bit system so that we can test
and close this defect.

Maintenance build M20050817 is available and contains these changes -->
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/ve/downloads/drops/M-M20050817-200508171531/index.html

Close, but didn't work.  From the log message it looks like the JNI link to the
existing compiled library didn't like the rename of the Java package.

I was able to successfully test using the Ubuntu live cd, so I can test other
attempts.  The live cd does not have gcc, but I can try to install it once it
boots up, if the native library needs to be recompiled.

Created an attachment (id=26321)
Updated libswt-gtk-print.so

Recompiled and working version of libswt-gtk-print.so for gtk x86_64.

Created an attachment (id=26322)
Screenshot of it working

Released the new .so files to 'org.eclipse.ve.swt\os\linux\x86_64' and
'org.eclipse.ve.swt\os\linux\ia64'.

I have a hunch that x86_64 and ia64 are not binary compatible.  If they were,
why would they have two separate downloads of Eclipse, SWT, etc.?

Yes, i think the binary files would be different which is why I created two
different folders for x86_64 and ia64. As far as Java goes both are 64 bit
handle widgets, which is why there is only one ImageCapture class. I just put it
as a place holder till somone can access a ia64 machine.

Given that the work is done, and only testing is needed,
moving this to Fixed state.
closed
